title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Yemen before 1 January 2017?
preds: There's just not much time left

The perceived shift in power of the US away from supporting Sunni sects because of the new president elect's perceived coziness with Russia which supports Iran and Syria (even when Assad and the Ayatollah are antagonists). The probability will get higher after the inauguration on Jan 20th.
With the bombing payback is a real possibility
Bizarre EWP criteria means deaths aren't deaths if the USA approves.
The possiblity is too high as expected.
Passage of time, and the fact that civilian deaths caused by Saudi Arabia and allies inside Yemen won't be considered.
Crisis watch, Aug. - Oct.: 29 Aug IS suicide bomb kills 60+ pro-govt. militia.  Most violence is military / militia based.

The newspaper noted that since the Saudi-US war broke out in March 2015 at least 10,000 have died, including 4,000 civilians.

With a fellow forecaster encouragig me to read the fine print of the official definition from the home office, Saudi activities do not count so it is back to zero.

It's a poor country that is getting increasingly militarized from the outside. It just seems like the right conditions for a mass killing.  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-iran-idUSKCN12K0CX
Recent attacks by Saudis and possible advisers now being called war crimes, link https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/10/13/yemen-saudi-led-funeral-attack-apparent-war-crime
The history of Saudi bombing in Yemen has included enough period mass civilian casualties to seem to indicate a high probability that this will happen again in the next two and a half months.
As far as mass killing episodes this link sure sounds like one, https://www.rt.com/news/362037-yemen-blast-strike-killed/ question is who makes the call.

Whoever is doing the "counting" seems to be playing by WWWF (World Wide Wrestling Federation) rules.  Lots of incidents, links http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/french-woman-hostage-working-red-cross-released-yemen-42548337 and here http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/09/21/485790/yemen-saudi-airstrike-hudaydah and here http://www.globalresearch.ca/war-on-yemen-inhaling-poisonous-gas-saudi-arabia-launches-chemical-attack-on-sanaa-killing-civilians/5542172 Maybe the folks who run the Syrian "observatory" could crowdfund a little side bidness and call it the "Yemeni Obervatory"...
A number of capable actors exist

The Saudi-led coalition air strikes have caused the majority of civilian deaths, and will likely be the major cause of civilian deaths in the near future. However, it appears unlikely that these air strike deaths will be classified as mass killings. It seems too likely that they will be classified as accidental killings.
-Air strikes lead to 1,000 or more civilian deaths by 1/1/17: 45% chance (3,218 civilian deaths so far, roughly 2/3 from air strikes, 5 months to go ~ on average, 900 civilian deaths by 1/1/17 from air strikes) 
-Air strikes are classified as deliberate mass killings by 1/1/17: 5% chance (not really sure how to justify this number, the UN has voiced concern about the civilian death toll due to the air strikes, but it just seems very unlikely that they get classified as deliberate by 1/1/17. Maybe after a multi-year investigation something arises that suggestions they were deliberate)
-Rough estimate for mass killings due to air strikes is 2.25% (45% x 5%) The Houthi siege leading to food/medical supplies failing to arrive and this leading to mass killings  is another possibility.
-Houthi siege leading to food/medical supplies failing to arrive by 1/1/17: 90% chance. The aid situation is dire in Yemen and it seems likely that some aid, somewhere will fail to arrive due to Houthi activities
-This failure leads to 1,000 or more civilian deaths: 10%. Only 1/3 of civilian deaths have been attributed to the Houthi siege. It is a possibility that their activities will lead to an event that directly results in 1,000 civilian deaths, but given that the average rate of civilian deaths linked to the Houthi reaches roughly 500 deaths by 1/1/17, it seems there is an outside chance that their actions result in 1,000 or more deaths. We would have to have the standard deviation of deaths to be roughly 400 for there to be a 10% chance. 
-If an event like this did happen, however, i think there is a good chance that it get classified as a deliberate mass killing: 75%
-Rough estimate for mass killings due to Houthi is 6.8% (90% x 10% x 75%) Other sources of mass killings
-The recent examples of mass killings seemed to involve a stronger power oppressing dissenters with violence.  This does not seem to fit the description of the Houthi. The Houthi have not gained enough power yet and they seem to be fighting against the rich and powerful, so resorting to deliberate mass killings in the traditional sense (shooting into a crowd of protesters, or torturing opposition) don't seem likely. If they were able to gain majority control, then maybe this would be likely.
-The current government and Saudi coalition seem to be sticking with air strikes as their primary course of action. A significant ground force would seem more likely to result in a mass killings event.
- 2.5% chance for unforeseen other
Yemen is not well organized and authorities have lost control.

Raising to be closer to consensus;  believe the definition is problematic in that it is difficult to identify "civilian" casualties and since "peace" talks continue the "mass killings" numbers  will not be met. https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/cross-border-attack-from-yemen-kills-4-saudi-family-members/2016/08/01/25736856-57dc-11e6-8b48-0cb344221131_story.html

The U.N. human rights office has released its latest figures on civilian casualties in Yemen, showing more than 3,500 people have been killed and nearly 6,300 wounded since Saudi Arabia’s bombing campaign against the Houthi rebels began in March of last year. http://www.voanews.com/content/yemen-civilian-casualties/3370540.html The UN human rights chief has accused the Saudi-led coalition of causing twice as many civilian casualties as all the other forces fighting in Yemen.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-35842708 1/3rd of 3500 = 1050 which still meets the EWP's extremely political decision to exclude 2/3rds of casualties. The real total is 3x that.

decided to settle in at 10% (+1% from my initial forecast).
not sure what AQAP is going to do; not sure how the people killed by other actors will be counted

With this kind of mendacity coming  from the flip-flopping Toffs at the UN , link  http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/06/08/united-nations-saudi-arabia-coalition-yemen/85588502/   and certain nations seeking to meddle in electoral politics and street level disturbances in homelands of major world powers, the situation is looking more like it is playing by rules of World Wide Rassling Federation.  The decorum of diplomacy throughout "expanded"  and crowdfunded Horn of Africa, it can be argued, is being eradicated , cuz like John Kerry's "existentialist" meme on migration, diplomacy produced assimilated Arab apologists subjugated Islam.  Instead of Republican and Democratic primaries and conventions that cost billions. Are you ready for a Loya Jirga or its equivalent near where you call home?  http://www.rferl.org/content/afghanistan-loya-jirga-explainer/25174483.html   Maybe around 63rd and Stony Island in Chicago or Barbes-Rochechouart in Paris?
Mass killings are taking place all around the world. Yemen's ongoing war makes country vulnerable

The threshold for a mass killing is 1,000 noncombatant civilians:
http://www.earlywarningproject.com/definitions That seems like a steep limit at first glance and a look at the START Consortium's Global Terrorism Database confirms that terrorist attacks in Yemen have not killed more than about 800 people in a single year (2013):
https://www.start.umd.edu/gtd/search/Results.aspx?country=228 The US and UK have withdrawn from Yemen and there is no cohesive Yemeni government (Saleh is gone) to perpetrate mass killings on civilians:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qaeda_insurgency_in_Yemen#2016 Building on what Sjens said about OHCHR, and given the steep threshold for what constitutes a mass-killing, I'll give my initial prediction a low likelihood of this resolving as a "Yes."
It's one of those forecasts where you just have to look at the past. Still very unstable situation in Yemen.

Exceedingly political decision to exclude Saudi Arabian/Western Coalition kills as if the dead are less dead by executive fiat. The EWP is wearing its obvious  bias openly. And how will someone determine who exactly was the killer?  "The revelations prompted the UN to put the Saudi-led coalition fighting the war on a blacklist of child rights violators but the move was later reversed after the kingdom threatened to withdraw funding to UN agencies."
https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2016/7/5/houthi-rockets-kill-seven-children-in-yemens-marib "The situation in Taiz remains critical, with some of the heaviest and most sustained fighting in the country.  MSF-run and supported hospitals in Taiz have been receiving thousands of war wounded in recent months.  An increase in fighting in March, April and May necessitated the treatment of around 1,700 war wounded alone – most of the wounded coming from within the city where many civilians are caught in the middle of intense fighting. The patients MSF sees in Taiz are mainly suffering from injuries due to airstrikes, shelling, gun shots and, more recently, land mines. Movement in and out of the city remains restricted and dangerous for civilians and humanitarian actors."
http://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/yemen-crisis-update-july-2016
ISIS is in retreat pretty much everywhere else.  It needs to make a show somewhere.
Even the IS attacks are aimed at government forces.  Most civilian deaths seem to be due to war related air-strikes.

I don't believe the overall fog of war in Yemen to be appreciably different from when I last forecasted on the conflict with the exception of @Sjens comments about Al-Qaeda.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/285421 Being very bold on this initial forecast, but am prepared to jump.

The short time frame and apparent ongoing peace talks suggest a "mass killing" unlikely for now. 
1: "ADEN， Yemen， July 16 (Xinhua) -- A second round of the UN-facilitated peace talks between Yemen's warring parties resumed Saturday in Kuwait after a two-week break， government officials said."
1: http://english.sina.com/news/2016-07-17/detail-ifxuaiwa7085854.shtml  In addition (2) there seems an effort to resolve intra-Sunni conflicts that might contribute to additional killings.
"The Hadrami in general have always been conservative Sunni Muslims, some of whom went to extreme lengths religiously. However, their common goal to maintain and protect the Hadrami community identity is so strong to the extent that politically differing Hadrami factions are willing to work together to achieve this objective. Furthermore, AQAP in Yemen seems to have learned from its mistakes in Abyan, which was its regional hub for many years in the last two decades. Instead of seeming foreign and overtly strict, AQAP in Hadramaut adopted a rather accommodative rule, which was somewhat democratic, and it collaborated with other factions in the governorate."
2: http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/07/yemen-hadramout-forces-aqap-isis.html

http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=54476#.V48xa_moOuo
"The cessation of hostilities declared on 10 April to end nearly 16 months of conflict in Yemen has continued to provide relief from violence in many parts of the country, but serious violations have occurred, such as the shelling of a popular market in Taiz on 4 June, which resulted in 18 civilian deaths and tens of injuries. In addition, there have been violations of the truce in Marib, al Jawf, Taiz and in the border areas with Saudi Arabia. "
It looks like there is no more active conflict, so i am starting at 7%.

OHCHR says that between 26. March 2015 and the end of March 2016 around 6.000 people have been killed, over half of them are civilians. I would expect this death toll to rise, once better data is avaiable. I am very unsure if  better data will be avaiable though. However, this is a very bloody civil war with a lot of players and reprisal attacks between Shiites and Sunnis are already occuring.  Why only 9%?  
The deaths inflicted by any foreign force (e.g. Saudi-Arabia) do not resolve this question; most of the civilians die in S-A airstrikes. Many civilians get killed by other explosive weapons (IEDs, Surface-Air Missiles and so on) and in general it's very hard to establish if they got killed deliberately. In my view, the main risk factor for future mass killings would be Al-Qaida, who started to imitate the Islamic State in Syria & Iraq and established a very firm control over almost the complete coastal strip in the South of Yemen, make millions of dollars and recruit a lot of fighters. Edit: This is my initial forecast; I might (very likely) raise this in the coming days.
